ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RELEASE POLICIES

Motiva Enterprises LLC - Greensboro Terminal is a refined petroleum product distributor. The Greensboro Terminal is a light products, bulk petroleum storage terminal used in the storage and distribution of petroleum products to retail and commercial end-users in the vicinity of Greensboro, NC. The Terminal handles and stores various grades of unleaded gasoline, low-sulfur diesel, butane, ethanol, and various other petroleum based additives.

Motiva Enterprises LLC (Motiva) - Greensboro Terminal in Greensboro, NC is committed to operating and maintaining processes in a safe, reliable and environmentally sound manner. Motiva believes that excellent performance in health, safety, and the environment goes hand in hand with operating reliably, and that outstanding EHS performance is of paramount importance.

The Greensboro Terminal is designed, operated and maintained in a manner that protects the environment, as well as the health and safety of our employees, contractors and the community. Motiva promotes health, safety, and the environment through programs of awareness, compliance, prevention and protection. These programs include a combination of accidental release prevention and emergency response planning.

This document provides a brief overview of the comprehensive risk management activities that Motiva has designed and implemented, including:

A. A description of the facility and the use of regulated substances;
B. An overview of the accidental release prevention programs;
C. A five-year accident history for accidental releases of regulated chemicals;
D. An overview of the emergency response program; and
E. An overview of planned changes to improve safety.

A. STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES

The primary function of the Greensboro Terminal is to act as a refined petroleum distribution facility. The butane blending process has been classified as Program Level 3. No Program 1

or 2 processes containing regulated substances are identified. By virtue of the flammable effects associated with butane, it is necessary to observe certain safety precautions in handling butane to prevent unnecessary human exposure, to reduce the threat to employee health, and to minimize the threat and impact to nearby members of the community. Motiva Enterprises LLC - Greensboro Terminal is strongly committed to employee, public, and environmental safety and health. Safety at the Facility depends upon the manner in which butane is handled as well as the various safety devices incorporated into the design of the process. Furthermore, comprehensive training is provided to employees and contractors/visitors which reinforces the safety policies and procedures of the Greensboro Terminal.

The facility has fixed inventories of butane. Butane is received by truck (transports) and stored in one (1) storage vessel. Specifically, liquefied butane is off-loaded by truck for storage under pressure (pressure reliefs set at 250 psi on the storage vessel). The butane is pumped to an injection skid for direct injection into regular and premium unleaded gasoline lines feeding the site gasoline truck loading rack. Injection quantities are controlled via the blending/injection skid and autoanalyzer. Process safety controls include excess flow valves, low-melting point (<250F) feeds to pneumatic valves (fail safe), 85% fill shutoff on the vessel, emergency shut-off devices on the system and HMI, line thermal (pressure) reliefs, and grounding/interlock devices. Access to the Greensboro Terminal is restricted to authorized employees, management personnel and authorized contractors/visitors.

B. GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC
PREVENTION MEASURES

Motiva's accidental release prevention programs along with emergency planning and response programs allow effective management of the hazards posed by Butane to our employees, the public, and the en

cess.
-Regular safety meetings and safety awareness programs.
-Routinely scheduled safety inspections and audits.
-Frequent unit surveillance by operators, and "24/7" remote monitoring.

General Release Mitigation includes:

-Automatic (ESD and thermal actuated) and remotely operated shut-offs to limit release quantity.
-Strategically located valves to isolate leaks.
-Hydrocarbon detectors at key areas to warn of a chemical release with auto-shutdown functions.

General Emergency Response includes:

-Emergency alert system.
-Periodic emergency training for employees.
-Communication systems with local emergency responders and regulatory agencies.
-Emergency drills with plant personnel, regulatory agencies, and community emergency responders to enhance response skills and coordination among agencies.

Further, the Greensboro Terminal Butane Process complies with the National Fire Protection Association's (NFPA's) Liquefied Petroleum Gas (LPG) Code (NFPA-58) requirements for LP Gas storage. In addition to the presence of appropriate controls to prevent possible releases of butane, if a release does occur, a Facility Response Plan (FRP) is in place for the Facility and response activities are coordinated with the Greensboro Fire Department and Guilford County Emergency Services.

C. FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

The Greensboro Terminal has an excellent record of accident prevention. The Terminal keeps records for all significant accidental chemical releases that occur at our facility. There have been no accidents, for this process, within the past five (5) years resulting from the chemical release of materials (Butane) covered under the EPA RMP regulation.

D. EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

Response actions are coordinated with the Greensboro Fire Department. A Facility Response Plan (FRP) is in place to inform employees what to do in case of a release, fire, and to notify emergency responders when there is a need for a response. Motiva - Greensboro

Terminal complies with the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) Accident Prevention Rules (40 CFR Part 68 Subpart D), the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) standard and associated 14 elements (29 CFR Part 1910.119), and all applicable state and local laws and regulations. The butane blending system is designed, constructed, and maintained in accordance with NFPA #58 and the manufacturer's, instructions and recommendations. In the event of an emergency involving the Greensboro Terminal butane blending system, it is the policy of the Facility to initially contact the Greensboro Fire Department and request their assistance. The Facility maintains a trained (annually) incipient fire response capability. The Facility's emergency response plans are coordinated with the Greensboro Fire Department and Guilford County Emergency Services. The local first responders can participate and are welcome in training and exercise sessions for this Facility.

E. PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Motiva Enterprises, LLC is continually striving to make the Greensboro Terminal the safest and most reliable workplace possible for our employees, our neighbors and our community. In an effort to improve and promote system safety, Motiva looks for, and seeks employee input, on process safety improvements. Additionally, Motiva works cooperatively with the surrounding community.
